contents.text:
Student topics: Create an AI agent
Weekly study hours: 6
Duration in weeks: 8

Produce JSON only matching the provided schema

arguments.query: Create an AI agent with Microsoft technologies

content.text:
{"results":[{"title":"Discover, create, and onboard an agent","content":"# Discover, create, and onboard an agent
## Create an agent
To create an agent, follow these steps:
1. Select **Request** on the agent template details page.
 [![Request an agent.](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/media/onboard/agent-request.png)](media/onboard/agent-request.png#lightbox)
2. Admin approves the request in the Microsoft 365 admin center, activates the template, and assigns licenses and policies. Learn more in [Agent 365 Overview page in the Microsoft 365 admin center](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/manage/agent-365-overview).
3. After activation, select **Create** on the template page.
4. Configure the agent:
4.1. **Agent icon**: The icon that appears for the agent.
4.2. **Name (configurable)**: The name of the agent. Don't use spaces or special characters in the agent name.
4.3. **Agent description**: The description for the agent.
5. Select **Save** to finish.
## Onboard an agent
After you create an agent, the AI agent appears in your organization chart under the creator's supervision. You can interact with the AI agent using Teams chat, channels, and meetings.
Configure more settings in the agent card in Teams or Copilot chat.
Pause or delete agents in Teams or Copilot chat. Tenant admins can also manage agents in the Microsoft 365 admin center.
Resources associated with an agent remain for 30 days after deletion.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/onboard#create-an-agent"},{"title":"Step 1: Your First Agent (programming-language-csharp)","content":"# Step 1: Your First Agent (programming-language-csharp)
Create an agent and get a response — in just a few lines of code.
```dotnetcli
dotnet add package Azure.AI.OpenAI --prerelease
dotnet add package Azure.Identity
dotnet add package Microsoft.Agents.AI.OpenAI --prerelease
```
Create the agent:
Run it:
```csharp
Console.WriteLine(await agent.RunAsync("What is the largest city in France?"));
```
Or stream the response:
```csharp
await foreach (var update in agent.RunStreamingAsync("Tell me a one-sentence fun fact."))
{
    Console.Write(update);
}
```
Tip
See the [full sample](https://github.com/microsoft/agent-framework/blob/main/dotnet/samples/01-get-started/01_HelloAgent.cs) for the complete runnable file.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/agent-framework/get-started/your-first-agent"},{"title":"AI-guided setup for Agent 365","content":"# AI-guided setup for Agent 365
## Run the AI-guided setup
3. **Configuration values** — Resource group, location, agent name, manager email, and App Service plan (for Azure-hosted) or agent name and manager email (for self-hosted).
4. **Derived value confirmation** — Review auto-generated names for the agent identity, blueprint, and user principal.
5. **Manifest review** — Confirm that your `manifest.json` is updated with your agent's name, description, and developer information.
Tip
The AI agent shows real values from your Azure subscription as examples when it asks for configuration inputs. You can accept the suggestions or provide your own values.
### Step 5: Complete post-deployment tasks
After the CLI commands finish, the AI agent provides instructions for manual steps that require browser interaction:
1. **Configure the agent in Teams Developer Portal** — Set the agent type and bot ID.
2. **Create an agent instance** — Request an instance from Teams and have an admin approve it.
3. **Test the agent** — Send messages to your agent in Teams to verify it works.
For detailed instructions on these post-deployment steps, see [Create agent instances](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/developer/create-instance).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/developer/ai-guided-setup#run-the-ai-guided-setup"},{"title":"Create agent instances","content":"# Create agent instances
Important
You need to be part of the [Frontier preview program](https://adoption.microsoft.com/copilot/frontier-program/) to get **early access** to Microsoft Agent 365. Frontier connects you directly with Microsoft’s latest AI innovations. Frontier previews are subject to the existing preview terms of your customer agreements. As these features are still in development, their availability and capabilities may change over time.
After you publish your agent and make it available in the Microsoft admin center, you can create agent instances and agent users. These instances and users use the agent blueprint and agent code you created.
This article breaks down the process into three main steps:
1. Configure agent in Teams developer portal
2. Create agent instance
3. Test your deployed agent
If you have challenges, refer to the Troubleshooting section.
## Prerequisites
1. Agent blueprint correctly set up as per [Setup agent blueprint step](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/developer/registration).
2. Agent application correctly published as per [Publish agent to Microsoft admin center](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/developer/publish).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/developer/create-instance"},{"title":"Create and deploy an agent with Microsoft 365 Agents SDK","content":"# Create and deploy an agent with Microsoft 365 Agents SDK
The Microsoft 365 Agents SDK enables you to build custom engine agents by using the AI stack of your choice, then deploy them to Microsoft 365 Copilot. With the Microsoft 365 Agents Toolkit for Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code, you can use the built-in templates to scaffold your projects.
The SDK supports integration with a wide range of models and orchestrators—including Azure Foundry, Semantic Kernel, OpenAI Agents, LangChain, or custom-built solutions. You can even combine multiple agents built with different technologies and surface them through Microsoft 365 Copilot.
## What you can do with the Microsoft 365 Agents SDK
You can use the Microsoft 365 Agents SDK to:
1. **Build agents quickly** and surface them across multiple channels, including Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams.
2. **Use your preferred AI services** to implement agentic patterns. The SDK is model- and orchestrator-agnostic - giving you full flexibility.
3. **Customize agent behavior** based on the capabilities of each client channel. For example, you can tailor your agent to respond to specific events or actions in Copilot, Teams, or other platforms.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-365-copilot/extensibility/create-deploy-agents-sdk"},{"title":"Microsoft Agent Framework agent types (programming-language-csharp)","content":"# Microsoft Agent Framework agent types (programming-language-csharp)
The Microsoft Agent Framework provides support for several types of agents to accommodate different use cases and requirements.
All agents are derived from a common base class, `AIAgent`, which provides a consistent interface for all agent types. This allows for building common, agent agnostic, higher level functionality such as multi-agent orchestrations.
## Default Agent Runtime Execution Model
All agents in the Microsoft Agent Framework execute using a structured runtime model. This model coordinates user interaction, model inference, and tool execution in a deterministic loop.
![AI Agent Diagram](https://learn.microsoft.com/agent-framework/media/agent.svg)
Important
If you use Microsoft Agent Framework to build applications that operate with third-party servers or agents, you do so at your own risk. We recommend reviewing all data being shared with third-party servers or agents and being cognizant of third-party practices for retention and location of data. It is your responsibility to manage whether your data will flow outside of your organization's Azure compliance and geographic boundaries and any related implications.
## Simple agents based on inference services
Agent Framework makes it easy to create simple agents based on many different inference services. Any inference service that provides a [`Microsoft.Extensions.AI.IChatClient`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/ai/microsoft-extensions-ai#the-ichatclient-interface) implementation can be used to build these agents. The `Microsoft.Agents.AI.ChatClientAgent` is the agent class used to provide an agent for any [IChatClient](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.extensions.ai.ichatclient) implementation.
These agents support a wide range of functionality out of the box:
1. Function calling.
2. Multi-turn conversations with local chat history management or service provided chat history management.
3. Custom service provided tools (for example, MCP, Code Execution).
4. Structured output.
To create one of these agents, simply construct a `ChatClientAgent` using the `IChatClient` implementation of your choice.
```csharp
using Microsoft.Agents.AI;

var agent = new ChatClientAgent(chatClient, instructions: "You are a helpful assistant");
```
To make creating these agents even easier, Agent Framework provides helpers for many popular services. For more information, see the documentation for each service.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/agent-framework/agents/"},{"title":"Technology plan for AI agents","content":"# Technology plan for AI agents
## Build AI agents
Choose a build path based on your organization's technical capabilities, timeline, and control requirements. Microsoft provides two primary platforms, Foundry (PaaS) and Copilot Studio (SaaS), with GPUs and containers (IaaS) as a third option.
[![Diagram showing build agent options across three platforms: Microsoft Foundry (pro-code with declarative agents, workflows, and hosted agents), Microsoft Copilot Studio (low-code with retrieval and task agents), and GPUs & Containers (custom infrastructure with code-first frameworks).](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/cloud-adoption-framework/ai-agents/images/build-overview.png)](images/build-overview.png#lightbox)
[Overview of AI agent build options comparing three deployment paths. Microsoft Foundry offers pro-code development with declarative agents for focused tasks, workflows for multi-step orchestration, and hosted agents with managed runtime. Microsoft Copilot Studio provides low-code development with prebuilt connectors and retrieval and task agent capabilities. GPUs & Containers support custom infrastructure using Visual Studio Code and GitHub for maximum flexibility in agent deployment.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/cloud-adoption-framework/ai-agents/images/build-overview.png#lightbox)
*Figure 3. Microsoft's AI agent build options.*
### Microsoft Foundry
[Microsoft Foundry](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/what-is-azure-ai-foundry?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) provides a platform-as-a-service (PaaS) environment for no/low-code agent development (declarative agents) or pro-code agent development (hosted agents). Foundry lets you pick your own models, and it consolidates runtime, orchestration, and integration into a managed environment. You don't need to manage the underlying virtual machine or Kubernetes infrastructure. See the following image for more capabilities:
[![Diagram showing the Microsoft Foundry architecture including authoring, orchestration, and runtime layers.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/cloud-adoption-framework/ai-agents/images/foundry-overview.png)](images/foundry-overview.png#lightbox)
[Overview of the Microsoft Foundry architecture. The diagram illustrates the flow from authoring tools to the managed runtime environment. It highlights key components including the model catalog, agent orchestration engine, and integration capabilities with external data and tools.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/cloud-adoption-framework/ai-agents/images/foundry-overview.png#lightbox)
*Figure 4. Overview of Microsoft Foundry's AI capabilities.*","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/cloud-adoption-framework/ai-agents/technology-solutions-plan-strategy#build-ai-agents"},{"title":"Discover, create, and onboard an agent","content":"# Discover, create, and onboard an agent
Important
1. You need to be part of the [Frontier preview program](https://adoption.microsoft.com/copilot/frontier-program/) to get **early access** to Microsoft Agent 365. Frontier connects you directly with Microsoft’s latest AI innovations. Get hands-on with breakthrough features, share your insights with product teams, and help shape the future of AI. Frontier previews are subject to the existing preview terms of your customer agreements. As these features are still in development, their availability and capabilities may change over time.
You discover approved agent templates in your Microsoft 365 tenant. Agent templates are preconfigured templates for AI-powered Agent 365 agents in Microsoft 365. These templates define the agent’s capabilities, identity, and compliance settings. Users can add and configure, also known as *onboard* agents after admin approval to automate tasks and enhance team productivity.
## Prerequisites
1. You need admin approval for your request in the Microsoft 365 admin center before creating an agent.
2. You need a "Microsoft Agent 365 Frontier" subscription enabled by the tenant admins in the Microsoft 365 admin center. This 25-seat subscription allows hiring autonomous agents.
## Discover agent templates
Agent templates are available in the Microsoft 365 Copilot Store under **Agents for your team** or in the **Apps** area in Microsoft Teams. All users in the tenant can find and view agent templates.
[![Available agents in Teams.](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/media/onboard/discover-agent-teams.png)](media/onboard/discover-agent-teams.png#lightbox)
Users can select an agent template from the **Agents for your team** category in Teams and the Microsoft 365 Agent store. 
When you select a template, the detail pane shows:
1. Description and skills
2. Developer information
3. Required licenses and policies","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/onboard"},{"title":"Technology plan for AI agents","content":"# Technology plan for AI agents
## Build AI agents
1. **Activity protocol, A2A, & integration with M365/Agent 365.** Foundry supports the [Activity Protocol](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/agents-sdk/activity-protocol) and agent-to-agent (A2A) patterns for standardized messaging. Agents can be published to [Microsoft 365](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/how-to/publish-copilot?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) and [Agent 365](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/how-to/agent-365?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) to surface capabilities directly in user workflows.
2. **Multi-agent workflows.**[Workflows](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/workflow?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) orchestrate complex business processes by handling sequential logic, conditional branching, and state management across multiple agents.
3. **Declarative agents.**[Prompt-based agents](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/development-lifecycle?view=foundry&preserve-view=true#types-of-agents) rely primarily on model reasoning and instructions, simplifying updates and versioning for behavior-driven agents.
4. **Hosted agents.** Code-first, [hosted agents](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/hosted-agents?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) support custom libraries or frameworks. This option provides a managed runtime that handles provisioning and scaling while allowing full code control.
5. **Models from.** The [Model catalog](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-studio/how-to/model-catalog) includes models from OpenAI, Anthropic, Meta, and Mistral, allowing selection based on specific performance, latency, and cost requirements.
6. **Memory.**[Managed memory](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/agent-memory?view=foundry&preserve-view=true&tabs=python) maintains conversation context. For strict data sovereignty requirements, a bring-your-own (BYO) memory store option is available.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/cloud-adoption-framework/ai-agents/technology-solutions-plan-strategy#build-ai-agents"},{"title":"Tutorial: Build an agentic web app in Azure App Service with Microsoft Agent Framework or Foundry Agent Service (.NET)","content":"# Tutorial: Build an agentic web app in Azure App Service with Microsoft Agent Framework or Foundry Agent Service (.NET)
## Create and configure the Microsoft Foundry resource
**Microsoft Agent Framework**
1. In the [Foundry portal](https://ai.azure.com), make sure the top **New Foundry** radio button is set to active and create a project.
2. Deploy a model of your choice (see [Microsoft Foundry Quickstart: Create resources](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/quickstarts/get-started-code?view=foundry&preserve-view=true#create-resources)).
3. From top of the model playground, copy the model name.
4. The easiest way to get the Azure OpenAI endpoint is still from the classic portal. Select the **New Foundry** radio button, then **Azure OpenAI**, and then copy the URL in **Azure OpenAI endpoint** for later.
 ![Screenshot showing how to copy the OpenAI endpoint and the foundry project endpoint in the foundry portal.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/app-service/media/tutorial-ai-agent-web-app-semantic-kernel-foundry-dotnet/foundry-project-openai-endpoint.png)
**Foundry Agent Service**
1. In the [Foundry portal](https://ai.azure.com), make sure the top **New Foundry** radio button is set to active and create a project.
2. In the home page, copy the **Project endpoint** for later.
3. Select **Start building** > **Create agent** and follow the prompt.
4. In the new agent's playground, create an OpenAPI tool to call your web app by selecting **Tools** > **Add** > **Custom** > **OpenAPI tool** > **Create**. In the **Setup** pane, add an action with the OpenAPI spec tool. Use the OpenAPI schema that you get from the deployed web app and **anonymous** authentication. For detailed steps, see [How to use the OpenAPI spec tool](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/how-to/tools/openapi?view=foundry&preserve-view=true).
 Your application code is already configured to include the server's `url` and `operationId`, which are needed by the agent. For more information, see [Connect to OpenAPI Specification](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/how-to/tools/openapi?view=foundry&preserve-view=true#prerequisites).
5. Be sure to select **Save**.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/app-service/tutorial-ai-agent-web-app-semantic-kernel-foundry-dotnet#create-and-configure-the-microsoft-foundry-resource"}]}

results.title: Discover, create, and onboard an agent
results.content:
# Discover, create, and onboard an agent
## Create an agent
To create an agent, follow these steps:
1. Select **Request** on the agent template details page.
 [![Request an agent.](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/media/onboard/agent-request.png)](media/onboard/agent-request.png#lightbox)
2. Admin approves the request in the Microsoft 365 admin center, activates the template, and assigns licenses and policies. Learn more in [Agent 365 Overview page in the Microsoft 365 admin center](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/manage/agent-365-overview).
3. After activation, select **Create** on the template page.
4. Configure the agent:
4.1. **Agent icon**: The icon that appears for the agent.
4.2. **Name (configurable)**: The name of the agent. Don't use spaces or special characters in the agent name.
4.3. **Agent description**: The description for the agent.
5. Select **Save** to finish.
## Onboard an agent
After you create an agent, the AI agent appears in your organization chart under the creator's supervision. You can interact with the AI agent using Teams chat, channels, and meetings.
Configure more settings in the agent card in Teams or Copilot chat.
Pause or delete agents in Teams or Copilot chat. Tenant admins can also manage agents in the Microsoft 365 admin center.
Resources associated with an agent remain for 30 days after deletion.

results.title: Step 1: Your First Agent (programming-language-csharp)
results.content:
# Step 1: Your First Agent (programming-language-csharp)
Create an agent and get a response — in just a few lines of code.
```dotnetcli
dotnet add package Azure.AI.OpenAI --prerelease
dotnet add package Azure.Identity
dotnet add package Microsoft.Agents.AI.OpenAI --prerelease
```
Create the agent:
Run it:
```csharp
Console.WriteLine(await agent.RunAsync("What is the largest city in France?"));
```
Or stream the response:
```csharp
await foreach (var update in agent.RunStreamingAsync("Tell me a one-sentence fun fact."))
{
    Console.Write(update);
}
```
Tip
See the [full sample](https://github.com/microsoft/agent-framework/blob/main/dotnet/samples/01-get-started/01_HelloAgent.cs) for the complete runnable file.

results.title: AI-guided setup for Agent 365
results.content:
# AI-guided setup for Agent 365
## Run the AI-guided setup
3. **Configuration values** — Resource group, location, agent name, manager email, and App Service plan (for Azure-hosted) or agent name and manager email (for self-hosted).
4. **Derived value confirmation** — Review auto-generated names for the agent identity, blueprint, and user principal.
5. **Manifest review** — Confirm that your `manifest.json` is updated with your agent's name, description, and developer information.
Tip
The AI agent shows real values from your Azure subscription as examples when it asks for configuration inputs. You can accept the suggestions or provide your own values.
### Step 5: Complete post-deployment tasks
After the CLI commands finish, the AI agent provides instructions for manual steps that require browser interaction:
1. **Configure the agent in Teams Developer Portal** — Set the agent type and bot ID.
2. **Create an agent instance** — Request an instance from Teams and have an admin approve it.
3. **Test the agent** — Send messages to your agent in Teams to verify it works.
For detailed instructions on these post-deployment steps, see [Create agent instances](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/developer/create-instance).

results.title: Create agent instances
results.content:
# Create agent instances
Important
You need to be part of the [Frontier preview program](https://adoption.microsoft.com/copilot/frontier-program/) to get **early access** to Microsoft Agent 365. Frontier connects you directly with Microsoft’s latest AI innovations. Frontier previews are subject to the existing preview terms of your customer agreements. As these features are still in development, their availability and capabilities may change over time.
After you publish your agent and make it available in the Microsoft admin center, you can create agent instances and agent users. These instances and users use the agent blueprint and agent code you created.
This article breaks down the process into three main steps:
1. Configure agent in Teams developer portal
2. Create agent instance
3. Test your deployed agent
If you have challenges, refer to the Troubleshooting section.
## Prerequisites
1. Agent blueprint correctly set up as per [Setup agent blueprint step](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/developer/registration).
2. Agent application correctly published as per [Publish agent to Microsoft admin center](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/developer/publish).

results.title: Create and deploy an agent with Microsoft 365 Agents SDK
results.content:
# Create and deploy an agent with Microsoft 365 Agents SDK
The Microsoft 365 Agents SDK enables you to build custom engine agents by using the AI stack of your choice, then deploy them to Microsoft 365 Copilot. With the Microsoft 365 Agents Toolkit for Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code, you can use the built-in templates to scaffold your projects.
The SDK supports integration with a wide range of models and orchestrators—including Azure Foundry, Semantic Kernel, OpenAI Agents, LangChain, or custom-built solutions. You can even combine multiple agents built with different technologies and surface them through Microsoft 365 Copilot.
## What you can do with the Microsoft 365 Agents SDK
You can use the Microsoft 365 Agents SDK to:
1. **Build agents quickly** and surface them across multiple channels, including Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams.
2. **Use your preferred AI services** to implement agentic patterns. The SDK is model- and orchestrator-agnostic - giving you full flexibility.
3. **Customize agent behavior** based on the capabilities of each client channel. For example, you can tailor your agent to respond to specific events or actions in Copilot, Teams, or other platforms.

results.title: Microsoft Agent Framework agent types (programming-language-csharp)
results.content:
# Microsoft Agent Framework agent types (programming-language-csharp)
The Microsoft Agent Framework provides support for several types of agents to accommodate different use cases and requirements.
All agents are derived from a common base class, `AIAgent`, which provides a consistent interface for all agent types. This allows for building common, agent agnostic, higher level functionality such as multi-agent orchestrations.
## Default Agent Runtime Execution Model
All agents in the Microsoft Agent Framework execute using a structured runtime model. This model coordinates user interaction, model inference, and tool execution in a deterministic loop.
![AI Agent Diagram](https://learn.microsoft.com/agent-framework/media/agent.svg)
Important
If you use Microsoft Agent Framework to build applications that operate with third-party servers or agents, you do so at your own risk. We recommend reviewing all data being shared with third-party servers or agents and being cognizant of third-party practices for retention and location of data. It is your responsibility to manage whether your data will flow outside of your organization's Azure compliance and geographic boundaries and any related implications.
## Simple agents based on inference services
Agent Framework makes it easy to create simple agents based on many different inference services. Any inference service that provides a [`Microsoft.Extensions.AI.IChatClient`](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/ai/microsoft-extensions-ai#the-ichatclient-interface) implementation can be used to build these agents. The `Microsoft.Agents.AI.ChatClientAgent` is the agent class used to provide an agent for any [IChatClient](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.extensions.ai.ichatclient) implementation.
These agents support a wide range of functionality out of the box:
1. Function calling.
2. Multi-turn conversations with local chat history management or service provided chat history management.
3. Custom service provided tools (for example, MCP, Code Execution).
4. Structured output.
To create one of these agents, simply construct a `ChatClientAgent` using the `IChatClient` implementation of your choice.
```csharp
using Microsoft.Agents.AI;

var agent = new ChatClientAgent(chatClient, instructions: "You are a helpful assistant");
```
To make creating these agents even easier, Agent Framework provides helpers for many popular services. For more information, see the documentation for each service.

results.title: Technology plan for AI agents
results.content:
# Technology plan for AI agents
## Build AI agents
Choose a build path based on your organization's technical capabilities, timeline, and control requirements. Microsoft provides two primary platforms, Foundry (PaaS) and Copilot Studio (SaaS), with GPUs and containers (IaaS) as a third option.
[![Diagram showing build agent options across three platforms: Microsoft Foundry (pro-code with declarative agents, workflows, and hosted agents), Microsoft Copilot Studio (low-code with retrieval and task agents), and GPUs & Containers (custom infrastructure with code-first frameworks).](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/cloud-adoption-framework/ai-agents/images/build-overview.png)](images/build-overview.png#lightbox)
[Overview of AI agent build options comparing three deployment paths. Microsoft Foundry offers pro-code development with declarative agents for focused tasks, workflows for multi-step orchestration, and hosted agents with managed runtime. Microsoft Copilot Studio provides low-code development with prebuilt connectors and retrieval and task agent capabilities. GPUs & Containers support custom infrastructure using Visual Studio Code and GitHub for maximum flexibility in agent deployment.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/cloud-adoption-framework/ai-agents/images/build-overview.png#lightbox)
*Figure 3. Microsoft's AI agent build options.*
### Microsoft Foundry
[Microsoft Foundry](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/what-is-azure-ai-foundry?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) provides a platform-as-a-service (PaaS) environment for no/low-code agent development (declarative agents) or pro-code agent development (hosted agents). Foundry lets you pick your own models, and it consolidates runtime, orchestration, and integration into a managed environment. You don't need to manage the underlying virtual machine or Kubernetes infrastructure. See the following image for more capabilities:
[![Diagram showing the Microsoft Foundry architecture including authoring, orchestration, and runtime layers.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/cloud-adoption-framework/ai-agents/images/foundry-overview.png)](images/foundry-overview.png#lightbox)
[Overview of the Microsoft Foundry architecture. The diagram illustrates the flow from authoring tools to the managed runtime environment. It highlights key components including the model catalog, agent orchestration engine, and integration capabilities with external data and tools.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/cloud-adoption-framework/ai-agents/images/foundry-overview.png#lightbox)
*Figure 4. Overview of Microsoft Foundry's AI capabilities.*

results.title: Discover, create, and onboard an agent
results.content:
# Discover, create, and onboard an agent
Important
1. You need to be part of the [Frontier preview program](https://adoption.microsoft.com/copilot/frontier-program/) to get **early access** to Microsoft Agent 365. Frontier connects you directly with Microsoft’s latest AI innovations. Get hands-on with breakthrough features, share your insights with product teams, and help shape the future of AI. Frontier previews are subject to the existing preview terms of your customer agreements. As these features are still in development, their availability and capabilities may change over time.
You discover approved agent templates in your Microsoft 365 tenant. Agent templates are preconfigured templates for AI-powered Agent 365 agents in Microsoft 365. These templates define the agent’s capabilities, identity, and compliance settings. Users can add and configure, also known as *onboard* agents after admin approval to automate tasks and enhance team productivity.
## Prerequisites
1. You need admin approval for your request in the Microsoft 365 admin center before creating an agent.
2. You need a "Microsoft Agent 365 Frontier" subscription enabled by the tenant admins in the Microsoft 365 admin center. This 25-seat subscription allows hiring autonomous agents.
## Discover agent templates
Agent templates are available in the Microsoft 365 Copilot Store under **Agents for your team** or in the **Apps** area in Microsoft Teams. All users in the tenant can find and view agent templates.
[![Available agents in Teams.](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/media/onboard/discover-agent-teams.png)](media/onboard/discover-agent-teams.png#lightbox)
Users can select an agent template from the **Agents for your team** category in Teams and the Microsoft 365 Agent store. 
When you select a template, the detail pane shows:
1. Description and skills
2. Developer information
3. Required licenses and policies

results.title: Technology plan for AI agents
results.content:
# Technology plan for AI agents
## Build AI agents
1. **Activity protocol, A2A, & integration with M365/Agent 365.** Foundry supports the [Activity Protocol](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/agents-sdk/activity-protocol) and agent-to-agent (A2A) patterns for standardized messaging. Agents can be published to [Microsoft 365](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/how-to/publish-copilot?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) and [Agent 365](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/how-to/agent-365?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) to surface capabilities directly in user workflows.
2. **Multi-agent workflows.**[Workflows](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/workflow?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) orchestrate complex business processes by handling sequential logic, conditional branching, and state management across multiple agents.
3. **Declarative agents.**[Prompt-based agents](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/development-lifecycle?view=foundry&preserve-view=true#types-of-agents) rely primarily on model reasoning and instructions, simplifying updates and versioning for behavior-driven agents.
4. **Hosted agents.** Code-first, [hosted agents](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/hosted-agents?view=foundry&preserve-view=true) support custom libraries or frameworks. This option provides a managed runtime that handles provisioning and scaling while allowing full code control.
5. **Models from.** The [Model catalog](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-studio/how-to/model-catalog) includes models from OpenAI, Anthropic, Meta, and Mistral, allowing selection based on specific performance, latency, and cost requirements.
6. **Memory.**[Managed memory](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/concepts/agent-memory?view=foundry&preserve-view=true&tabs=python) maintains conversation context. For strict data sovereignty requirements, a bring-your-own (BYO) memory store option is available.

results.title: Tutorial: Build an agentic web app in Azure App Service with Microsoft Agent Framework or Foundry Agent Service (.NET)
results.content:
# Tutorial: Build an agentic web app in Azure App Service with Microsoft Agent Framework or Foundry Agent Service (.NET)
## Create and configure the Microsoft Foundry resource
**Microsoft Agent Framework**
1. In the [Foundry portal](https://ai.azure.com), make sure the top **New Foundry** radio button is set to active and create a project.
2. Deploy a model of your choice (see [Microsoft Foundry Quickstart: Create resources](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/quickstarts/get-started-code?view=foundry&preserve-view=true#create-resources)).
3. From top of the model playground, copy the model name.
4. The easiest way to get the Azure OpenAI endpoint is still from the classic portal. Select the **New Foundry** radio button, then **Azure OpenAI**, and then copy the URL in **Azure OpenAI endpoint** for later.
 ![Screenshot showing how to copy the OpenAI endpoint and the foundry project endpoint in the foundry portal.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/app-service/media/tutorial-ai-agent-web-app-semantic-kernel-foundry-dotnet/foundry-project-openai-endpoint.png)
**Foundry Agent Service**
1. In the [Foundry portal](https://ai.azure.com), make sure the top **New Foundry** radio button is set to active and create a project.
2. In the home page, copy the **Project endpoint** for later.
3. Select **Start building** > **Create agent** and follow the prompt.
4. In the new agent's playground, create an OpenAPI tool to call your web app by selecting **Tools** > **Add** > **Custom** > **OpenAPI tool** > **Create**. In the **Setup** pane, add an action with the OpenAPI spec tool. Use the OpenAPI schema that you get from the deployed web app and **anonymous** authentication. For detailed steps, see [How to use the OpenAPI spec tool](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/how-to/tools/openapi?view=foundry&preserve-view=true).
 Your application code is already configured to include the server's `url` and `operationId`, which are needed by the agent. For more information, see [Connect to OpenAPI Specification](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/how-to/tools/openapi?view=foundry&preserve-view=true#prerequisites).
5. Be sure to select **Save**.

arguments.query: Building AI agents using Microsoft tools and frameworks such as Azure OpenAI, Agent Framework, Copilot, Foundry, or integrating AI into Microsoft 365. Include beginner-to-intermediate content relevant to creating and deploying an AI agent.

Core skills needed for creating, programming, and deploying AI agents using Microsoft technologies, Copilot, OpenAI, or agent frameworks. Include getting started and troubleshooting modules relevant for practical AI agent building.

contents.text: {"rationale":"Recommendations prioritize step-by-step, practical modules on building AI agents with Microsoft tools, especially Copilot Studio and Azure OpenAI, with additional coverage of best practices for solution and lifecycle management. The selected paths and modules are well-suited for an 8-week, 6-hours/week self-study format due to their depth, hands-on focus, and direct connection with the student's goals.","learningPaths":[{"title":"Application lifecycle management for the Power Platform","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/training/paths/application-lifecycle-management/","estimatedHours":2,"relevance":"Introduces application lifecycle best practices, essential for deploying and managing AI agents and related solutions using Microsoft Power Platform. Covers DevOps basics, solutions management, and use of GitHub Actions."}],"modules":[{"title":"Use Azure AI Services for Language in a Microsoft Copilot Studio","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/cognitive-service-power-virtual-agents/","skillFocus":"Hands-on guide to integrating Azure AI language services into custom Copilot Studio bots/agents, covering setup, definition, deployment, and troubleshooting."},{"title":"Introduction to DevOps","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/introduction-to-devops/","skillFocus":"Core DevOps concepts needed for professional deployment and lifecycle management of AI-powered solutions."},{"title":"Solution Architect series: Plan application lifecycle management for Power Platform","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/application-lifecycle-management-architect/","skillFocus":"Strategic planning for AI agent environments, solution movement from development to production, and lifecycle management."},{"title":"Introduction to solutions for Microsoft Power Platform","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/introduction-solutions/","skillFocus":"Essentials of transporting apps and components between environments—important for iterative AI solution development."},{"title":"Introduction to GitHub Actions","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/introduction-to-github-actions/","skillFocus":"Automation and CI/CD for code-driven AI agent solutions."}],"targets":[{"title":"Azure AI Engineer Associate (Exam AI-102)","type":"Certification","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/certifications/azure-ai-engineer/"}]}
